Trend is away from humanities
By JORDAN GANTZ
According to an article in the
February 4 issue of The
Chronicle of Higher Education,
the number of college students
enrolled in vocational and
pre-professional fields is rising
while engineering is making a
comeback in popularity. At the
same time, enrollments in the
humanities are declining and
enrollments in the social sciences
are leveling off.
Data supplied by Hopkins
Registrar Robert Cyphers show
that the trend away from the
study of the humanities and
social sciences toward the study
of natural and engineering
science is evident to some degree
here. A comparison of Arts and
Sciences fall term undergraduate
majors at Hopkins for 1969-1973
shows a definite similarity to the
trend of undergraduate majors at
the national level.
In the natural sciences, the
percentage of undergraduate
majors has risen from 35.8
percent of all Hopkins
undergraduates in the fall of
1969 to 48.9 percent in the fall
of 1973. Meanwhile, majors in
the humanities have fallen from
16.5 percent to 9.8 percent and
in the social sciences from 28.3

percent to 27.7 percent after
reaching a high of 29.2 percent in
the fall of 1971.
Hopkins' undergraduates
majoring in engineering science
also fell from 13.1 percent in the
fall of 1969 to 5.7 percent in the
fall of 1972 before rising slightly
to 6.0 percent in 1973.
That the choice of majors of
this year's freshman class at
Hopkins not only runs opposite
to the national trend but also to
the school-wide trend reflects the
recent decision of the
administartion to seek a more
diverse student body with regard
to undergraduate majors.
Consequently, the number of
freshmen natural science majors
actually dropped at Hopkins
between 1972 and 1973 from
61.7 percent to 53.7 percent. In
addition, freshmen humanities
majors rose from 5.4 percent in
1972 to 8.6 percent in 1973 and
social and behavioral sciences
majors from 18.9 percent in
1972 to 21.9 percent in 1973.
Also, freshmen majoring in
engineering science increased
from 4.3 percent in 1972 to 5.9
percent in 1973.
The article in The Chronicle
reports that students are
apparently "abandoning

theoretical, abstract, and purely
academic fields for those that
relate directly to jobs."
Commenting on this situation,
Stanford University President
Richard W. Lyman said, "A few
years ago we seemed greatly
over-supplied with amateur
rhetoricians and street-corner
moralists. Now there seems a
danger of our becoming once
again over supplied with
careerists and technocrats of one
kind or another."

Nan Bailey: 'Ours is an oppression with a history'
The Chaplain's Office, in
conjunction with "Next Step: A
Festival of Women" a
month-long series of lectures
highlighting the role of women in
today's world, presented black
feminist Nan Bailey at this
week's Sunday Experience.
Bailey, a student at Brown
University, spoke as one
directly affected by the dual
stigma of being black and a
woman, a cause for which she has
joined the National Black
Feminist Association.
Black and Female
"Black women live a
phenomena of being black and

female in a sexist and racist
society," stated Bailey.
Reading from a prepared text,
the member of the Young
Socialist Alliance then went on
to expound the past history of
discrimination and exploitation
which her predecessors,
beginning at the time of slavery,
had undergone.
"Ours is an oppression that has
a history," Bailey commented.
Bailey cited examples of
sexual exploitation of female
slaves during the mid-19th
century and parallelled this
exploitation of black women to
that shown by present-day

society which, according to
Bailey, is reluctant to allow black
women to rise above the station
of domestics or housmaids.
According to 1969 statistics,
one out of five black women
worked as domestics. Their
average yearly income rated
$2,070.
"Black women have always
been the cheapest source of labor
available," she stated.
Bailey also cited the role in
which black women have played
in revolutionary activities, and
related this to their active
involvement in the Women's
Liberation Movement.

"Black women have played a
leading role in organizing
revolutionary activities."
Bailey cited Harriet Tubman, a
black woman active in the
underground railroad which
operated over a century ago to
allow slaves to escape from
plantations and flee to Northern
cities.
As for the relation between
Black women's liberation and its
white counterpart, Bailey
conceded a close correlation
between the two.
Strength
"There is a need of black
women to fight more effectively

for the issues that most directly
effect us," said Bailey, drawing
the line between the two groups.
Bailey added that the "above
ground formation" of the Black
Liberation Movement would lend
strength to the impact of the
Women's Liberation Movement,
"which is not viewed as the real
economic and social reform
movement that it is."
"There's a basis of unity on a
variety of issues," she paralled
between the two groups.
"But there's more at stake at
fighting back for black women,
because of the double
exploitation."

In any big city, there are to be found a number of large
institutions that go on and on, operating without ever
making any substantial effort to aid the community in
which they are situated. Many manufacturing firms operate
without any concern for the amount of pollution they may
create. Many businesses go on for years without giving any
thought to their hiring practices.
Non-commercial institutions, such as universities, often
operate without giving any thought to the burden their
tax-free status imposes on the city in which they are, or on
the citizens who live there. Certainly, for many years,
Hopkins has been no exception to this rule. While it is true
that the University has maintained a decent record of keeping its campus open to outsiders and that President Muller
exercised a commendable restraint last year in refusing to
wall off the campus, when concern over crime was at its
peak, Hopkins has really done very little to aid the declining neighborhod in which it stands.
So the announcement last week of a program under
which Hopkins will deposit some of its money in local
banks that agree to make mortgage loans to area residents
appears to be a step in the right direction. That the initial
